Literature Review: Reprogrammed metabolism plays a crucial role in the development and progression of colorectal cancer (CRC). CRC cells exhibit altered metabolic profiles, characterized by increased glycolysis, enhanced fatty acid synthesis, and decreased oxidative phosphorylation (1). This metabolic reprogramming enables CRC cells to thrive in nutrient-poor environments, facilitating rapid proliferation and tumor growth. Intestinal stem cells (ISCs), the primary cell of origin for CRCs, must adapt their metabolism to the complex microenvironment of the intestinal epithelium, which includes interactions with immune cells, stromal cells, commensal microbes, and dietary components (2). The intestinal microbiome has been implicated in CRC pathogenesis, with alterations in the gut microbiota contributing to the development of CRC (3). Emerging evidence suggests that modifiable risk factors, such as diet, play a significant role in CRC initiation and progression (4). This review aims to describe the metabolism of ISCs, diets that influence CRC initiation, CRC genetics and metabolism, and the tumor microenvironment, highlighting the mechanistic links between environmental factors, metabolic adaptations, and the tumor microenvironment in enhancing or supporting CRC tumorigenesis.
